results.title: Solar energy: how it works
results.brief_description: In order that energy from the sun be used it must be either concentrated, absorbed, trapped or converted. Simple experiments by children and commercial applications provide examples of how this can be done.
results.description: In order that energy from the sun be used it must be either concentrated, absorbed, trapped or converted. Simple experiments by children and commercial applications provide examples of how this can be done.

results.title: Solar energy
results.brief_description: Investigates the possibility of utilising solar radiation. Shows methods of obtaining heat and electricity from the sun, installations already in operation, production of heat for high temperature and metal research, and the domestic use of solar energy. Gives working Australian examples.

results.title: Solar cells outback
results.brief_description: Deals with applications of the new, cheaper, solar panels to produce electricity in outback Australia beyond the reach of the power grid. The potential of solar powered electric pumps to replace the windpump is also discussed in detail.

results.title: Sokhodeora
results.brief_description: Sokhodoera is a rice growing village located in the state of Bihar, North Eastern India. The filmmakers of this beautifully photographed documentary arrived in the village a year after it had suffered the worst famine in its history, gaining an insight into the lifestyle of the people of Sokhodoera, revealing an India that is vastly different to the impressions offered by those who visit the cities of India. The film focuses on Mahadev, an “untouchable” who obtained and developed his farm with the help of a neighbouring ashram, highlighting his lifestyle and his role in his community.

results.title: Sojourn in rural Japan: a youth hostel trip
results.creator_credit: Shu Taguchi Productions and Japan. National Tourist Organisation
results.brief_description: A youth hostel trip in the Tohoku district where, more than in any other part of Japan, the old and simple ways still remain. This film shows the Towada National Park and the Yamagata and Hiraizumi areas which attract young people all the year round.

results.title: Soils and foundations
results.brief_description: This film studies the problem of building rigid brick and masonry houses on troublesome soils, such as clay soils, which swell and shrink due to seasonal wetting and drying. Soil identification gives the key to data on the physical properties and bearing capacity of various soils. These properties determine the correct foundation practice which will prevent cracking and disfiguration. The film is intended primarily for architects and engineers.

results.title: Soil: more than dirt
results.brief_description: This program lokks at land degredation due to salting, soil erosion and soil structure decline because of over use of the land itself, this in turn leads to low agricultural productivity. The research done by the department of Conservation, Forests and Land suggests ways and means of better land management practices. No other credits

results.title: Soil test
results.brief_description: A soil expert from the Summerland Experimental Farm in the Okanagan Valley, British Columbia, demonstrates the way that a soil moisture meter can tell when it is time to irrigate. Hosted by Julian Biggs.

results.title: Soil structure decline
results.creator_credit: Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture and Gerry North
results.brief_description: After a short period of cultivationn, our soils are losing their inherent structure and are becoming difficult to work. This program discusses soil structure decline and its effect on agricultural productivity.

results.title: Soil fertility in South Africa
results.creator_credit: South Africa. Dept. of Education. Film Services Union and South African Government
results.brief_description: A note of warning is sounded and attention focused on various malpractices which lead to the deterioration or total destruction of the thin layer of fertile top soil. Remedial and preventative measures are explained and the farmer is encouraged to co-operate with the State in its campaign against retrogressive practices.
